author: @NimbleBitty
text:
Let me say up front that both Conscious Lee and Olay have presented topics and discussions to me that challeneged my fundamental understandings about issues (from the white, southern frame of reference) and i genuinely appreciate both of yall's work.

I do have a question for anyone. I'm just now getting into really trying to educate myself on all these different topics. I've picked up books from various white authors who present a word I already know and can identify well, i.e. white authors (Marx, Lenin, Naomi Klein, and some others.) However after reading Angela Davis's "Freedom is a Constant Struggle" and really being introduced to the intersectionality, and the ways these issues that i focus on from my frame of reference need to be fought with the people from all struggles. Her explanation of the way in which each struggle intersects drove me to read something else outside of my comfort zone. Thus, I'm currently reading "The Autobiography of Malcolm X" and whew it is so far beyond my comfort zone! That said, I love hearing his perspective on a world I cannot understand, and I'm doing my best to listen and learn. 

I say all that wayyyy too much exposition to ask, you mentioned Huey P. Newton and others during your conversations. What are some their works (or whatever you, the reader of this comment, think is an important) that I can read to further educate myself? 

Thanks again for the amazing discussions!

replies.author: @ashlybuck5706
replies.text: I think you could look into The wretched of the earth by Franz Fanon as well.

replies.author: @ashlybuck5706
replies.text: Also I just looked up specifically a book written by Mr. Huey P. Newton called To Die for The People

replies.author: @NimbleBitty
replies.text: ‚Äã@ashlybuck5706 thanks for the tip! It's actually in my library, so I need to move it up a bit in the tbr.

author: @CheeseLoversUnited
text: this was a conversation I enjoyed. I mention the following from a place of respect, but in re: to the conversation of defining afro pessimism, I think it's incorrect to say that the majority came out of world War 2 understanding that the antisemitism that fueled the holocaust was wrong. Anti semetism was alive and well in Europe (and all the Allied countries...) before, after and during world War 2 in different ways. While the holocaust is acknowledged in a lot of places as an a gross injustice, that doesn't necessarily lead straight into the idea that therefore the ideas that fueled the holocaust are equally totally repudiated. In the same way that while most will places will  awknowledge that the Atlantic slave trade was a gross injustice, that doesn't mean that the white supremacist framework that facilitated it has been repudiated

author: @iams.b.campbell
text:
Love Olay and Conscious Lee!

Only push back I have for conscious is that the world doesn‚Äôt h8 black folks. America does but there are countries where we‚Äôre valued, safe and appreciated. I feel like it‚Äôs important to make the distinction that we have options that are safe and identify the unsafe places by name. Not generalize the statement.

author: @celestialbeing4767
text: Not many even heard of the "Conscious community". It's a mess of various schools of thought. Examples are Hotep or Kemet, and biblical factions like black Israelites. Then you have your moors, Muslim folk. They debate each other on various topics. Mostly religious, historical stuff. Doing a show and tell style of discourse. PowerPoint presentations, showing where you get your material from.

author: @LethalLemonLime
text:
22:53 okay actually now I need to understand this cause I don't see how it's not anti semitic to be anti Palestinian? I don't think they're uniquely semitic because Jewish people are semites but so are the Palestinians.

Edit: Oh he said because the phrasing antisemitism was created only for Jewish people. But I'd argue that it's misleading and purposefully left out other semites. Like why did they choose semitic instead of anti-jew. Why choose semitic unless they wanted to frame them as the only semites?
